Award.AwardTitle: Wall-crossings in quasimap theory and applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project aims to expand on the investigator's study of compactifications of moduli spaces of maps from curves to a large class of GIT quotient targets. These compactifications, called moduli spaces of stable quasimaps, produce new curve-counting invariants, which are expected to be related by wall-crossing formulas with Gromov-Witten invariants. In recent work with Kim, the PI has found such wall-crossing formulas in genus zero and they turn out to give a significant generalization of Givental's toric mirror theorems. The PI will work to extend the theory in several directions. First, the wall-crossing formulas should extend to curves of higher genus, and the resulting theory for Calabi-Yau three-folds is conjecturally equal to the BCOV B-model theory of the mirror Calabi-Yau, but WITHOUT changing coordinates by the mirror map. The PI plans to prove this conjecture at least for local Calabi-Yau targets. Other projects will provide extensions to orbifold targets (with applications to the Crepant Resolution Conjecture), and to Landau-Ginzburg models (with applications to the Calabi-Yau/LG correspondence). Further applications, such as a proof of the general Abelian/Non-abelian Correspondence in Gromov-Witten theory are also expected.

This research is in the field of algebraic geometry, an old and highly developed branch of mathematics, which at its core is the study of geometric shapes defined by polynomial equations. Moduli theory is concerned with how these shapes deform. The moduli spaces studied by the investigator have deep connections with the mirror symmetry phenomenon discovered in string theory, a very active area of theoretical physics. In the last two decades, the results and techniques from algebraic geometry, especially the theory of moduli spaces, have been successfully employed in string theory. On the other hand, ideas from string theory have opened up new directions of research in mathematics by suggesting striking conjectures and at the same time putting old unsolved problems into a new light. The project will continue this fruitful interaction by offering new insights on mirror symmetry at higher genus.

This award is co-funded by the Algebra and Number Theory and the Topology programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal direction of investigation in this project concerned the "counting" of surfaces, such as spheres, tori (one can think of a torus as the surface of a doughnut) and in general surfaces of arbitrary genus - doughnuts with arbitrary number of holes - sitting in certain spaces known as Calabi-Yau manifolds. Outside of mathematics, one of the main interests in studying the geometry of (particularly six-dimensional) Calabi-Yau manifolds, and in the understanding of the counts of surfaces mentioned above, comes from String Theory. This is a branch of physics which aims to create a framework permitting the unification of quantum mechanics and general relativity. In this framework, the space-time will be ten-dimensional, with the additional six dimensions "curled" in a compact space of tiny size. Consistency of the theory requires that this compact space be Calabi-Yau. One of the many predictions of String Theory is the phenomenon known as ``Mirror Symmetry": Calabi-Yau spaces should come in pairs, such that surface counts in one of them correspond to completely different (but often easier to calculate) geometric quantities on the other. This correspondence is conjecturally achieved via a so-called "mirror transformation". The origin of the mirror transformation appeared quite mysterious at the time it was introduced. For these facts, and many more fascinating aspects of String Theory, the interested reader may wish to consult the best-selling popular science book "The Elegant Universe".


The methods employed by the investigator in his study belong to the area of mathematics known as Algebraic Geometry. This is because most of the interesting Calabi-Yau spaces may be viewed as algebraic varieties: they are geometric shapes described by polynomial equations. Further, all surfaces we are interested in counting in such spaces may also be viewed as "algebraic curves over the complex numbers". 


The main outcome of the project is a series of results which serve to demystify the mirror transformation. Namely, the PI has introduced a family of surface-counting (or curve-counting, in algebro-geometric language) theories, depending on a parameter, with the following properties. When the parameter is very large, it recovers the usual counting from String Theory. As the parameter decreases towards zero, the counting formulas undergo certain discrete changes, and this happens infinitely many times. The PI has proved that when summing up all these changes, one obtains precisely the mirror transformation. Hence the appearance of the mirror transformation is dictated by the choice of curve-counting theory, and there is one such theory for which no transformation is needed. The results of the the PI are in fact much more general, in that they apply to a significantly larger class of geometries beyond the Calabi-Yau spaces, which are of great interest mathematically. In many of these cases, the formulas for the required transformations were not even guessed before the PI's work.


The PI has disseminated the above results in peer-reviewed publications. His contributions to training the younger generation of researchers include advising graduate students at the University of Minnesota and delivering two mini-courses on his curve-counting theories which were attended by graduate students and beginning postdoctoral researchers from several other US institutions.
